UNEMPLOYMENT SITUATION
(Statement)


    2. Mr Seah Peng Chuan asked the Minister for Labour and Welfare if he will make a statement on the present day situation on unemployment in Singapore; and what was the number of unemployed persons in Singapore as at 31st December, 1956.

    Mr Lim Yew Hock: In answer to a question in this House in February 1956, I explained that accurate numbers of unemployed persons in Singapore are not available. A study of the various factors which affect employment in Singapore does not suggest that there has been any appreciable change in the unemployment situation during the last 12 months. On the 31st of December, 1956, there were 7,842 persons actively seeking employment assistance through the Government Employment Exchange.

    Mr Seah Peng Chuan: Mr Speaker, Sir, is the Minister aware that only a small number of unemployed persons are registered with the Government Labour Exchange, that there are about 100,000 unemployed persons in Singapore, and that there were hundreds of unemployed people registered with Government Labour Exchange for five years ago and are still out of employment?

    Mr Speaker: Order. I must, of course, point out to hon. Members that supplementary questions are supplementary questions. They should not be read.

    Mr Lim Yew Hock: Sir, I find difficulty in understanding the supplementary question. If I understand it correctly, it is whether I am aware that there are more than 100,000 persons who are unemployed. Sir, with the resources at our service, may I tell him that there are not 100,000 persons unemployed?

    An hon. Member: Much more.

    Mr Lim Yew Hock: Much less.

COMMERCIAL ADVERTISEMENT
OF BRITISH COMPANIES
(Distribution by Information Services)


    4. Mr Lee Kuan Yew asked the Chief Secretary whether he is aware that commercial advertisement of British companies has been distributed by the Information Services and to state on whose authority such distribution was made.

    Mr Goode: Sir, think the hon. Member is probably referring to magazines and industrials reviews which are published by large corporations and federations of industries in the United Kingdom. These publications do not offer goods for sale but they convey information about technological developments, industrial organisations, trade unions, staff activities and other matters of general interest. They are well produced and abundantly illustrated with excellent photographs from many parts of the world and are very informative. They are distributed to public reading rooms, community centres and schools where, I am advised, they are very much appreciated. The distribution is the responsibility of the Director of Information Services under my general authority.

    Mr Lee Kuan Yew: Is the Hon. the Chief Secretary aware of the purpose of these large industrial concerns in

Column: 1192

putting forward these beautifully illustrated magazines containing a lot of useful information for their prospective buyers?

    Mr Goode: Yes, Sir, I am perfectly aware of the purpose.

    Mr R. Jumabhoy: Sir, is it not the duty of the United Kingdom Trade Commissioner to perform this duty instead of this Government?

    Mr Goode: Sir, I am not in a position to answer for the duties of the United Kingdom Trade Commissioner.

    Mr R. Jumabhoy: Do the Information Services give the same information to other Commonwealth countries?

    Mr Goode: Yes, Sir, if they wish it.

    Mr Lee Kuan Yew: Is it proposed to give the same facilities to beautifully illustrated brochures of the German, the Japanese, the Russian, the Chinese enterprises?

    Mr Goode: They are not members of the Commonwealth, Sir.

HOUSING AUTHORITY
(Statement)


    6. Mr Lee Choon Eng asked the Minister for Local Government, Lands and Housing if he will make a statement on the progress in the establishment of a Housing Authority to replace the Singapore Improvement Trust.

    Inche Abdul Hamid Bin Haji Jumat: Mr Speaker, Sir, the establishment of a new Housing Authority presents many complex and intricate problems. The question was first considered by the Committee on Local Government whose recommendations were accepted by Government with certain modifications. Since then, Sir, the Government has given much thought to the problem and has now decided what policy should be adopted with regard to the constitution and functions of the new organisation. From 1st January this year Mr J. M. Fraser, Chairman and Manager of the Singapore Improvement Trust, has been released from his managerial duties and has been with the Ministry of Local Government, Lands and Housing on secondment for special duties in connection with the establishment of the new Housing Authority, including the preparation of the necessary legislation pertaining thereto and also with the preparation of comprehensive town planning legislation. He will also plan and organise the change-over from the Improvement Trust to the new Authority.

    Mr Lee Choon Eng: Mr Speaker, can the Minister tell us how long we will have to wait for the Committee to finalise its report so that the establishment of this Housing Authority could be implemented?

    Inche Abdul Hamid: Mr Speaker, Sir, I cannot give a definite date, but I can

Column: 1194

assure the Member for Queenstown that it will only be a matter of months.

REDUCTION OF S.I.T. RENTALS


    7. Mr Lee Choon Eng asked the Minister for Local Government, Lands and Housing when can S.I.T. tenants expect a reduction of rentals as promised by the Minister early last year.

    Inche Abdul Hamid Bin Haji Jumat: Mr Speaker, Sir, the hon. Member presumably refers to a statement which I made in this House on 8th February, 1956, when I said that the savings resulting from the reduction of the interest rate on S.I.T. loans to two per cent might well go towards the reduction of rentals of the cheapest houses. It will be seen, Sir, from the White Paper tabled this morning that the Government has closely examined the question of housing subsidies and has decided not to proceed with the proposal to subsidise housing by reducing the rate of interest on loans. The new method of subsidy proposed will make it possible in due course to undertake a comprehensive survey of all Trust rentals with a view to equalisation of rents. It is a long-term policy of Government, Sir, that ultimately the same rent should be paid for the same type of accommodation in all public housing estates. As an interim measure, certain immediate reliefs are proposed to which reference is made in the White Paper and it is hoped, Sir, that these will be effective from the 1st of February this year. I can also say here, Sir, that the measures to be proposed involve Government to the extent of a little over half a million dollars for 1957.

S.I.T. HOUSES ON WAR
DEPARTMENT LANDS


    8. Mr Lee Choon Eng asked the Minister for Local Government, Lands and Housing whether he is aware that the Singapore Improvement Trust has built on War Department lands houses now occupied by Army personnel, and to state on whose authority, out of what funds, and the terms on which such houses were built.

Column: 1195



    Inche Abdul Hamid Bin Haji Jumat: Mr Speaker, Sir, a thousand houses and ten shops were erected on War Department lands at Clementi Road by the Singapore Improvement Trust which was acting as agent for the Singapore Government. A loan of $3 million was approved by the Legislative Council in 1954. It was agreed that these houses should be occupied by families of local military personnel but that the houses will be vacated and handed over for housing the public as soon as alternative accommodation for these families has been built by the Army and that all houses would be handed over within a period of seven years from the time they were completed. The War Department is paying rent equivalent to the loan charges on the property and, in addition, maintenance charges amounting to 2 per cent of the cost of the buildings per annum.

    Mr Lee Choon Eng: Mr Speaker, Sir, can the Minister tell us if at this stage the scheme has been completed; and, if not, the number of units that have been completed and the number of units that the S.I.T. intends to build for the War Department to complete the scheme.

    Inche Abdul Hamid: Mr Speaker, Sir, I shall require notice of that question.

    Mr Lee Choon Eng: In that case, Sir, can the Minister tell us is it Government's policy then to build houses and, if not, is there a chance for the Government to stop the implementation of that scheme from now onwards?

    Mr Speaker: That is a different question.

TELOK AYER DIVISION (Flooding)

AMA KENG RESETTLEMENT


    10. Mr Goh Tong Liang asked the Minister for Local Government, Lands and Housing-

    (a) why have the agricultural roads in Ama Keng Resettlement not been made up yet;

    (b) when will he issue titles to the settlers in Ama Keng Resettlement.

    Inche Abdul Hamid Bin Haji Jumat: Mr Speaker, the reply to question (a) is that the Engineering Section of the Resettlement Claims of the Land Office has been fully occupied in building roads in newly opened-up resettlement areas. These have to be given priority as the lack of prepared resettlement sites was everywhere holding up the Government's building programme.

    The reply to question (b) , Sir, is that titles will be issued as soon as title survey of the area, which is now in hand, is completed.

LOW-COST HOUSING UNITS
(Number)


    11. Mr Seah Peng Chuan asked the Minister for Local Government, Lands and Housing-

    (a) the exact number of low-cost housing units built in the Colony in 1956;

Column: 1197



    (b) how many low-cost buildings are to be constructed in Singapore during 1957.

    Inche Abdul Hamid Bin Haji Jumat: Mr Speaker, Sir,

    (a) 1,261 housing units and eight shops were completed during 1956, while a further 2,521 were under construction at the end of the year. These figures are lower than originally expected owing to complications of land clearance and resettlement, since Government's intention has been to make proper provision for persons affected by new building projects. However, Sir, the Land Clearance and Resettlement Department has now been established and Government has set aside $4 million to provide for proper resettlement.

    (b) It is expected that 3,056 low-cost dwellings and 95 shops will be completed during 1957, while a further 4,000 will be under construction on 31st December, 1957.

    Mr Lee Kuan Yew: For the general information of Members in this Assembly, could we have a definition of a low-cost house?

    Inche Abdul Hamid: I shall require notice of that question, Sir.

    Mr Lee Choon Eng: Sir, can the Minister tell us then what was the total number of units earmarked for 1956 compared to the number of units that have been completed and those that are now under construction?

    Inche Abdul Hamid: I am afraid I cannot give an answer on the spot, Sir.

ENGLISH AND CHINESE
LANGUAGE SCHOOLS


    12. Mr Goh Tong Liang asked the Minister for Education-

    (a) what does he propose to do with the nearly 9,000 children who will not get places in the English-language schools in 1957;

    (b) how many children of school-age of both sexes are there who cannot get places in the Chinese-language schools in 1957.

Column: 1198



    Mr Chew Swee Kee: Mr Speaker, Sir, (a) the first question is somewhat misleading. It can only be satisfactorily answered if I explain briefly what our aim is and how far we have succeeded in achieving it. The first object we set out to achieve was to provide enough schools and to train enough teachers to give every child a six-year primary education. As the primary age group is now increasing at the rate of some 20,000 a year, this meant that 20,000 extra places a year had to be provided even to maintain the existing position with the age of admission to Government schools seven plus. In fact, more than 20,000 additional places are being provided each year, most of them in new Government schools, so that it has been possible to lower the age of admission to about six years eight months. Parents of children born in 1949, that is, seven years old on 1st January, 1957, and 1950 six-year olds were asked to register in August last year. Of 11,715 seven-year olds who were registered, every single one has been offered a place. Of 15,685 six-year olds, 6,610 have been offered places. The others will be given priority of admission, according to age and place of residence, to schools which will be opened later this year. Those who are not so admitted will be guaranteed places in 1958. The position this year has been complicated by late registrations and by the need to use some of the new Government primary school buildings to house Chinese middle school pupils.

    (b) it is impossible to give a definite answer to this question. Obviously it is easier for children to find places in some localities than others. There are too few schools in some of the crowded city areas and too few sites available for building new ones. On the other hand, it is not possible to build schools easily accessible to all children in rural areas. In general, however, the large numbers of children aged six and even five years old who are admitted to Chinese schools show that there is no real shortage of places. Fully-aided schools will, however, be required to follow the Government practice of giving priority of admission to older children.

ELECTRICITY AND TELEPHONES
FOR RURAL AREAS


    15. Mr Goh Tong Liang asked the Minister for Communications and Works whether he has any plans for supplying electricity and telephones to the remoter parts of the rural areas; and to state in

Column: 1200

what areas and by what dates such services will be available.

    Mr Francis Thomas: The Singapore Telephone Board are giving every consideration to the extension of the telephone system to all parts of the island. The Board's interim report on development plans has been published and laid at the Assembly sitting on the 5th of September last. Details are given in the report concerning proposals to expand many exchanges on the island, including Tanjong Katong, Bukit Timah, Paya Lebar, Pasir Panjang and so on.

    With regard to the installation of public call boxes, my Ministry has supplied the Board with a list of some 80 sites in the rural areas, and the Board have stated that nearly 80 per cent of these requirements will be met in the first quarter of 1957, which is very creditable indeed.

    The supply of electricity generally is a function of the local authorities, the City Council and the Rural Board. I am therefore not competent to comment on this matter.

REOPENING OF CONSTITUTIONAL TALKS IN LONDON
(Statement by the Chief Minister)


10.25 a.m.

    The Chief Minister (Mr Lim Yew Hock): Mr Speaker, Sir, I rise to make a statement on my London visit last month to arrange for the re-opening of constitutional talks with the Colonial Office.

    I understand, Sir, the local Press has been giving wide coverage to my informal talks, and for this the Government

Column: 1202

would like to express its thanks. Some of these reports, however, were of a speculative nature. Every time I was seen or interviewed by members of the Press, I had a smile for them and I had been able to laugh my way through many an awkward question. This might have accounted for the optimistic tone of the reports which have been coming through from London. I am not striking a pessimistic note at all, but I do wish to strike a note of caution, that, unless all the ingredients are there, the cake of Merdeka cannot be well and truly baked. I am, however, quite satisfied with the trend of the informal talks and can honestly say that the prospects are good and that success is within reach; but we can only achieve this if we lay our plans well and if we all make strenuous efforts to see to it that nothing happens in the meantime to jeopardise our chances. Let us march towards Merdeka in the full realisation that this means increasing responsibilities demanding the best that is in us in the fulfilment of the destiny of our people towards a better and a fuller life. This is a national issue and in this national issue let us not allow side issues to mar its success.

    And now, Sir, let me turn to the agreed agenda which reads:

    1. To take note of the items in the Constitutional Proposal by the United Kingdom Government as set out in Appendix 8 of Command Paper 9777 (Annexure L. to the Legislative Assembly Sessional Paper No. Cmd. 31 of 1956), which have already been agreed to in principle.

    2. Internal Security.

    3. External Relations and External Defence.

    4. Designation of Her Majesty's Representative in Singapore.

    5. Date of coming into force of the new Constitution.

    6. Position of civilian employees in the Armed Forces.

    7. Any other business.

    Item 1 means that what the Marshall delegation has gained during the last talks would remain, and this includes citizenship status for the many thousands of non-locally-born persons. I have heard it expressed in some quarters that

Column: 1203

I was willing to accept less than what has been offered to the Marshall delegation, and I hope this information will put an end to their loose talk.

    Item 2, Sir, is an important one - a very important one. It refers to the extent to which the new constitution would permit interference in our internal security problem. Hon. Members will recollect that the Marshall delegation asked for a Malayan to be the Chairman of the Defence and Security Council proposed by the Colonial Office, but this was turned down. Failure to reach agreement on this question was the main cause of the breakdown of the last talks. Since I took over office as Chief Minister last June, I have been giving this matter considerable thought and I have also had informal discussions with my friend Tunku Abdul Rahman. The proposal which I submitted to the Colonial Office under this heading calls for an Internal Security Council to be composed of equal representation by the Singapore Government and Her Majesty's Government and a Minister from the Federation of Malaya, under the chairmanship of the representative of Her Majesty's Government. Under the proposed set-up, it will be seen that the vote of the Federation member is the deciding factor in the Internal Security Council. My proposal is based on the fact that the Federation is more closely linked with us vis-a-vis internal security than the United Kingdom. In this connection, the people of Singapore remember with gratitude the assistance of the Federation during our October riots. As to be expected, Sir, the Colonial Office had some misgivings about this proposal. The opportunity was taken of the presence in London of Tunku Abdul Rahman, and there was a joint informal discussion of the three parties - the Federation Chief Minister, the Secretary of State for the Colonies, and myself. I am again indebted to Tunku Abdul Rahman for his fine and continued co-operation as a result of which the Colonial Office now considers that there is a basis for agreement.

    Item 3 on External Relations and External Defence is to be further discussed

Column: 1204

in the light of my proposal under item 2.

    Item 4 refers to the designation of Her Majesty's representative as apart from the representative of Her Majesty's Government. I pressed on for a Malayan Governor-General, and from the trend of the informal talks, I take heart that the new constitution may yet see a Malayan as the Queen's representative in a new State of Singapore.

    Item 5, Sir, refers to the date of coming into force of the new constitution, and hon. Members are already aware of the intention of the Government.

    Item 6, Sir, brings in for discussion the position of the many thousands of civilian employees in the Armed Services. This is a matter on which I will be holding discussions with the trade union organisations that represent them.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, the question that crops up in the mind of everyone, inside and outside the Assembly, is, "Will the delegation for the resumption of talks with the Colonial Office in March be an All-Party one or a Government one?" The answer to this question, Sir, is obvious. To ensure success, I must first of all ensure that there is unity in the delegation. I mean to ensure that the performance of the last delegation is not repeated. I want to bring a united force to London, a force that can be relied upon to bring the cake home. Another failure will be too much for the people of Singapore to bear. Another failure will mean a grave blow to the democratic forces in Singapore and will make the ground fertile for subversive forces to operate. I propose to call as soon as possible a conference of all Parties represented in the Assembly, after which I will be in a better position to make up my mind as to the composition of the delegation.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, during my meetings with the Secretary of State and with his officials, there was an air of cordiality and goodwill, and this has helped much to bring about a better understanding of the position. I hope the same spirit of cordiality and goodwill will prevail in March. I would like, Sir, to take this opportunity to express my

Column: 1205

thanks to Her Majesty's Government for their hospitality during my stay in London.

    Sir. I had several discussions with Malayan students in London, and I was impressed by their awareness of the trend of events in Malaya and by their enthusiasm and political acumen. This, indeed, augurs well for the future.

    Mr D. S.
